div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,161] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Mi­nimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding throe lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in new columns P.T. 20 pec line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are done in advance. P.0, Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices • 36, New Broad-street "2.0.
The Egyptian Gazette

div.head: GERMANY AND MOROCCO.
div.p: Count von Bulow's speech in the Reichstag yesterday, an epitome of which appear in our telegrams, clearly shows that Germany intends to have a finger in the Moorish pie, and from to-morrow, when the Kaiser lands at Tangier, a note development in the history of Morocco may not improbably be dated. We are also informed in A telegram from Paris that the Sultah is preparing to utilise the visit to the utmost, and has already begun to stiffen his opposition to the French policy. The situation is one which cannot be wholly pleasing to France. She has ear marked Morocco as her own, and she is not prepared to pull the chestnuts out of the fire for Germany any more than for England. Her dissatisfaction will not be diminished by the Kaiser's visit to Tangier, where he is to be received with every official honor, and where the Mi ore will welcome him as a protector against France encroachment- Now, is it too much to say that, before the disaster to the Russian arms, Germany would have been extremely careful how she touched France on a parti­cularly tender spot 1 Is it, again, not clear
that it is to interest of Germany to try to

make terms with France, who will be asked to buy off German interference in Morocco at the price -of concessions, the nature of which it is not possible to specify, but which may reason­ably be expected to bode no good to British trading interests when France shall be in a posi­tion to give valuable practical support to the trade of ono Power against the trade of another I The incident is not only significant in regard to Morocco, but it is part and parcel of the entire change which must come over the political situation throughout the world from the shrinkage of Russian prestige, and the utter collapse of the military power of the northern giant baa set Germany free to devote her attention— if she sues Hit—to sundry matters of interest to her which, aha could not so well took after while obsessed by the haunt­ing dread of an attack by a France-Russian combination.

div.head:
GERMANY AMD MOROCCO.
GERMANY'S POLICY.
FRENCH PRESS AND KAISER'S VISIT.

div.p: Count von Billow confirmed in the Reichstag that Germany did not seek any territorial advantage in Morocco. She will simply see to the maintenance of the policy of the "open door." (Havas)

Count von Billow, speaking in the Reichstag, said that Germany's policy regarding the equal rights of all trading nations in Morocco is unchanged, but if an attempt were made to change the international status of that country or the control of the "open door," Germany must take increased heed that her economic interests in Morocco are not endangered. Germany, therefore, intended to enter into communication with the did ten forthwith. (R.)

The semi-official Press affects to be uncon­cerned as regards the Kaiser's journey to Tangier, but the tone of the newspapers gene­rally in both countries shows that some signi­ficance is attached to the visit. It is certain that the Sultan is prepared to utilize the visit to the utmost, and the same is already stiffening his opposition to the French policy, (R.)

Howe or Commons. —Mr. Walton's motion condemning Mr. Barfour's policy of fiscal retaliation was adopted without a division, the Ministerialists deliberately abstaining from voting, in pursuance of the Government s deci­sion not to participate in fiscal debates. (R.)

div.head:
BRITISH MISSION TO KABUL
AGREEMENT CONCLUDED.

div.p: The British mission Las concluded an agree meet, and started on its return home. (R.)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: EDITOR. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
London, March 23.
No appointment has yet been made to the
command of the British troops in Egypt. Feuding the
appointment of Major-General Slade's successor
Brigadier- General G.M. Bullock, C.B., commands at
Cairo.
Sir George S. White, V.C., will command at
Gibraltar until June next. This is owing to the
Aproaching visit oi King Edward to the Rock, and the
reception of his Sovereign will be amongst the last of
the official acts of the old hero who "kept the flag
flying" in Natal.
Major-General A. G. Raper, C.V.O., is about to
vacate the command of the Infantry Brigade at "Gib."
There is no foundation for the rumor that a battalion
of infantry is to be withdrawn from the Rock.
detachment of the 3rd Battalion Aids do,
which was left behind at Meerut, when the
battalion moved to Aden, has the battalion,
which is now at full growth.
Master and Captain G. W. Anderson,
Highlanders, Director of Stores, Egyptian Army, has
received permission from the King to accept and
wear the insignia of the Third Class of the Medjidieh,
conferred on him by the Khedive in recognition of his
services with the Egyptian Army. Captain
Anderson has seen a lot (it campaigning, including
the Afghan War 1878-80, the actions of perwar
Kabol, Mattoon Zaidabad, Charasiah, capture of
Cabul, and Roberts' march to Kandahar (medal with
four clasps and Kandahar Star), Egyptian War 1382,,
Tel-el- kebir, aud the capture of Cairo (medal with,
clasp and Khedive's Star); Bechuanaland Expedition
1884; and Kitchener's advance to Khartoum,
including Atbara and Omdurman (mentioned in
dispatch, honorary ranked captain, medal, and
Khedive's medal with two clasps).
Early next month the battleship "London," and
the cruisers "Abdukir" and "Lancaster," Of the
Mediterranean Fleet, will leave Malta for England to
pay off.
The new Japanese battleship "Kajima'' was
launched at EG wick yesterday. The ship was named
by Madame Avakaraway in presence of Viscount
Hayashi. The "Kashima" measures 425 feet in
length, '8 feet m beam, with a displacement oi
16,400 tons, She will carry an armament of four 12-
inch, four 10-inch, end twelve G inch breech-loading
guns and eighteen smaller guns, and a crew of 980
all told, the is the tenth ship built for Japan at
Elswick, but of course she cannot be delivered
during the present war. At the subsequent luncheon
Viscount Hayashi, Japanese Minister, in responding
to the toast of "The Japanese Empire," stated that in
his country successes over Russia more than a
dozen British-built battleships had

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
THE "HIGHER CRITICISM IN ARABIC.
div.p: To The EDITOR or THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,— I sympathies with "Grammarian's" latter published in your issue of the 25th instant. I do not admire Dirr's Colloquial Arabic Grammar, but nevertheless, the criticism on it was too contemptuous. In the same way, your critic slashed mercilessly into Colon el Green's Grammar some time ago. and therefore "Grammarian" may bo justified is resenting the autocratic tone of the very superior person who does your criticisms for you. A little humility, a little conciliation would not hurt year critic, who, after all, is bat * foreign student, of indifferent pronunciation, of limited knowledge of the vernacular, who would not hold his own in a friendly conversation among educated Egyptians, His own spoken Arabic would be a confusion of classical and vulgar— oh, ye gods and little fishes, what a confusion!

II there is one thing that makes us ridiculous in the eyes of the Egyptians it is our foolishness in trying to write grammars of Arabic, of modem-Arabic, of Arabic as wo think it ought to spoken and written, linage an Egyptian bringing out a grammar and vocabulary of English, London Cockney, of dialects of Lancashire, Essex, Berkshire, Somerset, all muddled op together, as spoken by our railway porters, housemaids and shoeblacks throughout the country, Vulgar Arabic is dreadfully vulgarian, as Mr. Mantalini might say, it is "dem'd low." Thera is only ORE Arabic, and that is the Classical language. Anything else is anarchy and confusion, each man putting forth his own ideas and talking as if he bad discovered Arabia and had made it his private property. Fence to ail such, just 200 years ago, the great Lord Bacon, not yet Solicitor General, came to spend the winter in Egypt, accompanied by a young student of the Inner Temple, John Selden, and many other learned lawyers and future judges.
Selden became enamored of the colloquial language, and compiled a thick, congealed book on the subject, of which the MB. may still be found in the Khedivial Library. Bacon was gathering local
color for his play of "Antony and Cleopatra," but he
found time to discuss the grammar of Arabic, as he
and his learned disciples dwelt together is the
desert suburbs to the north of Cairo. Bacon did not
believe in modern Arabic, he loved Latin, he had
just brought out his "Advancement of Learning," and
he engaged a sheikh to translate it into good
classical Arabia. The MB. may be seen in the
Khedivial Library, dated. 1605-6. Bacon used to
chaff John Selden, and to call him a Daniel come to
judgment, a just judge, and eventually persuaded
that good youth to abandon the attempt to teach the
Arabs their own language. And now, 220 years
have passed, and lo I we are at the same old game
